commit_message:
Fix for not passing CA cert to nova-compute

The charm looked for `keystone_juju_ca_cert` on disk
instead of
`/usr/local/share/ca-certificates/keystone_juju_ca_cert.crt`

Change-Id: Ib7cfdadc3a75fca951792ef2c2e2b454b1ad021d
Closes-Bug: #1915504
(functionally equivalent to commit bd3e24f359e75f6fc1a47346274630fffbceb2b0)

commit_message:
Validate configdrive string format

The ironicclient CLI silently passes invalid JSON as a configdrive
blob, which fails much later with a confusing errors. Add an early
check in the API.

Change-Id: Ifa9993a9454fe036a600ca8b855397321d4fbc04

commit_message:
Cleanup dead mistral actions and workbooks

- Removes unused mistral actions
- All mistral workbooks
- Custom filter for undercloud nova
- mistral entry points as we don't have mistral

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/775749

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-08 10:21:40.000000000', 'message': "Stop configuring install_command in tox.

Currently, we are overriding 'install_command' to use 'pip'. This is
considered poor behavior and 'python -m pip' should be used instead:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value.

Change-Id: Id33d429630f103413ebe8d1d2a999da884224d65
"}, {'created': '2020-09-09 04:30:48.000000000', 'message': 'Stop configuring install_command in tox.

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value.

Change-Id: Id33d429630f103413ebe8d1d2a999da884224d65
'}]
commit_message:
Stop configuring install_command in tox.

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value.

Change-Id: Id33d429630f103413ebe8d1d2a999da884224d65

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-11-03 20:19:45.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Only ask tpool.Proxy to autowrap vir* classes

I668643c836d46a25df46d4c99a973af5e50a39db attempted to fix service wide
pauses by providing a more complete list of classes to tpool.Proxy.

While this excluded libvirtError it can include internal libvirt-python
classes pointed to by private globals that have been introduced with the
use of type checking within the module.

Any attempt to wrap these internal classes will result in the failure
seen in bug #1901383. As a result this change simply ignores any class
found during inspection that doesn't start with the `vir` string, used
by libvirt to denote public methods and classes.

Closes-Bug: #1901383
Co-Authored-By: Daniel Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
libvirt: Only ask tpool.Proxy to autowrap vir* classes

I668643c836d46a25df46d4c99a973af5e50a39db attempted to fix service wide
pauses by providing a more complete list of classes to tpool.Proxy.

While this excluded libvirtError it can include internal libvirt-python
classes pointed to by private globals that have been introduced with the
use of type checking within the module.

Any attempt to wrap these internal classes will result in the failure
seen in bug #1901383. As a result this change simply ignores any class
found during inspection that doesn't start with the `vir` string, used
by libvirt to denote public methods and classes.

Closes-Bug: #1901383
Co-Authored-By: Daniel Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I568b0c4fd6069b9118ff116532f14abb46cc42ab
(cherry picked from commit 0d2ca53bb86b8e4a3c44855cb5ef57f223462543)
(cherry picked from commit 048a3337a8c98ec8fc138083376430ffb9027f67)

commit_message:
Add retries to module installation with r10k

Since the modules are git cloned when installed via r10k and
clones may fail due to some network glich, adding retries should
help in these cases.

We randomly hit failures during git clone in RDO promotion
jobs running on ci.centos.org, adding retries to r10k
installation to handle those random failures.

Added function 'retry_cmd' which can also be used
with other commands.

Conflicts:
  functions

Also squashed below two commits:-

Retry sealert command on failure

We randomly see issues while running sealert
in RDO puppet promotion pipeline, sealert fails with:-
"SELinux is disabled or we can't open a policy file"
As per logs selinux is enabled and selinuxfs is mounted
so seems it's some filesystem issue.

Locally was able to reproduce only with selinux disabled
or umount /sys/fs/selinux. Adding retries in hope to
fix these random failures.

Change-Id: Icb07742d328827a41132cdd6a6c2bcfa3cde11ec
(cherry picked from commit 425f454bdcb264eb80b305b67a5d4bcd4e04aadb)

Improve retry_cmd function to handle set -e

In run_tests.sh we use 'set -e' which makes
script fail as soon as error hit but we don't
want to fail in case of retries, this patch fixes it.

Change-Id: Ia33ff3dbb88317171143a43e5b1c674038187254
(cherry picked from commit ec57a35931babc9698a8399ca5c76773f069e377)

Change-Id: I5f3b94eaa5a65c76877363e9ca41684445c9cb12
(cherry picked from commit 8d5b34c5522c17f0246d208d0104c86e3325250e)

commit_message:
Drop lower-constraints job

Lower-constraints is not a requirement of the OpenStack Python PTI
[0] and there currently is a discussion on the mailing list [1]
about dropping the test, with the oslo team already having done
so [2].

The new dependency resolver in pip fails due to incompatible
dependency versions in our lower-constraints file, meaning that
we were never providing any real guarantees with it.

To unblock the CI, I am disabling lower-constraints job for now,
with the option to reenable it in case we fix the constraints,
and based on the outcome of the mailing list discussions and
consensus.

[0]. https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/pti/python.html
[1]. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019672.html
[2]. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019659.html

Change-Id: I7dc8c3aaa3e6676d70015e956a9c0dfac5da2fb8

commit_message:
Add retries to r10k command and sealrt command

This is the squashed commit of the following three pacthes in master,
which introduce retries in r10k command and sealert command to avoid
random failure possibly caused by temporal issues.

---
Add retries to module installation with r10k

Since the modules are git cloned when installed via r10k and
clones may fail due to some network glich, adding retries should
help in these cases.

We randomly hit failures during git clone in RDO promotion
jobs running on ci.centos.org, adding retries to r10k
installation to handle those random failures.

Added function 'retry_cmd' which can also be used
with other commands.

Change-Id: I5f3b94eaa5a65c76877363e9ca41684445c9cb12
(cherry picked from commit 8d5b34c5522c17f0246d208d0104c86e3325250e)

---
Retry sealert command on failure

We randomly see issues while running sealert
in RDO puppet promotion pipeline, sealert fails with:-
"SELinux is disabled or we can't open a policy file"
As per logs selinux is enabled and selinuxfs is mounted
so seems it's some filesystem issue.

Locally was able to reproduce only with selinux disabled
or umount /sys/fs/selinux. Adding retries in hope to
fix these random failures.

Change-Id: Icb07742d328827a41132cdd6a6c2bcfa3cde11ec
(cherry picked from commit 425f454bdcb264eb80b305b67a5d4bcd4e04aadb)

---
Improve retry_cmd function to handle set -e

In run_tests.sh we use 'set -e' which makes
script fail as soon as error hit but we don't
want to fail in case of retries, this patch fixes it.

Change-Id: Ia33ff3dbb88317171143a43e5b1c674038187254
(cherry picked from commit ec57a35931babc9698a8399ca5c76773f069e377)

---

Change-Id: I687f173d8d8a07c22d222f1ae90aca8c74d53d9c

commit_message:
Drop lower-constraints job

Lower-constraints is not a requirement of the OpenStack Python PTI
[0] and there currently is a discussion on the mailing list [1]
about dropping the test, with the oslo team already having done
so [2].

The new dependency resolver in pip fails due to incompatible
dependency versions in our lower-constraints file, meaning that
we were never providing any real guarantees with it.

To unblock the CI, I am disabling lower-constraints job for now,
with the option to reenable it in case we fix the constraints,
and based on the outcome of the mailing list discussions and
consensus.

[0]. https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/pti/python.html
[1]. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019672.html
[2]. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019659.html

Change-Id: I84eb172f77354102d95bd9f82b3d2b4a54dc7180

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE

UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is old name and deprecated
-https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul-jobs/python-roles.html#rolevar-tox.tox_constraints_file
This allows to use lower-constraints file as more
readable way instead of UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=<lower-constraints file>.

Change-Id: I98ee2b16e65ed7a9a13e9f5193c90d588bf98375

commit_message:
relinker: Pass whole conf dicts around

This lets the diskfile managers have access to things like reclaim age,
which it important now that we're doing rehashing. While we're at it,
pass better log_level values around.

Change-Id: Ibe1d18d94f9d5af7654a41e2086ea1a7b42e0750

[{'created': '2021-02-18 06:15:16.000000000', 'message': 'Add retries to module installation with r10k

Since the modules are git cloned when installed via r10k and
clones may fail due to some network glich, adding retries should
help in these cases.

We randomly hit failures during git clone in RDO promotion
jobs running on ci.centos.org, adding retries to r10k
installation to handle those random failures.

Added function 'retry_cmd' which can also be used
with other commands.

Also squashed below two commits:-

Retry sealert command on failure

We randomly see issues while running sealert
in RDO puppet promotion pipeline, sealert fails with:-
"SELinux is disabled or we can't open a policy file"
As per logs selinux is enabled and selinuxfs is mounted
so seems it's some filesystem issue.

Locally was able to reproduce only with selinux disabled
or umount /sys/fs/selinux. Adding retries in hope to
fix these random failures.

Change-Id: Icb07742d328827a41132cdd6a6c2bcfa3cde11ec
(cherry picked from commit 425f454bdcb264eb80b305b67a5d4bcd4e04aadb)

Improve retry_cmd function to handle set -e

In run_tests.sh we use 'set -e' which makes
script fail as soon as error hit but we don't
want to fail in case of retries, this patch fixes it.

Change-Id: Ia33ff3dbb88317171143a43e5b1c674038187254
(cherry picked from commit ec57a35931babc9698a8399ca5c76773f069e377)

Change-Id: I5f3b94eaa5a65c76877363e9ca41684445c9cb12
(cherry picked from commit 8d5b34c5522c17f0246d208d0104c86e3325250e)

commit_message:
Add retries to module installation with r10k

Since the modules are git cloned when installed via r10k and
clones may fail due to some network glich, adding retries should
help in these cases.

We randomly hit failures during git clone in RDO promotion
jobs running on ci.centos.org, adding retries to r10k
installation to handle those random failures.

Added function 'retry_cmd' which can also be used
with other commands.

Also squashed below two commits:-

Retry sealert command on failure

We randomly see issues while running sealert
in RDO puppet promotion pipeline, sealert fails with:-
"SELinux is disabled or we can't open a policy file"
As per logs selinux is enabled and selinuxfs is mounted
so seems it's some filesystem issue.

Locally was able to reproduce only with selinux disabled
or umount /sys/fs/selinux. Adding retries in hope to
fix these random failures.

Change-Id: Icb07742d328827a41132cdd6a6c2bcfa3cde11ec
(cherry picked from commit 425f454bdcb264eb80b305b67a5d4bcd4e04aadb)

Improve retry_cmd function to handle set -e

In run_tests.sh we use 'set -e' which makes
script fail as soon as error hit but we don't
want to fail in case of retries, this patch fixes it.

Change-Id: Ia33ff3dbb88317171143a43e5b1c674038187254
(cherry picked from commit ec57a35931babc9698a8399ca5c76773f069e377)

Change-Id: I5f3b94eaa5a65c76877363e9ca41684445c9cb12
(cherry picked from commit 8d5b34c5522c17f0246d208d0104c86e3325250e)

commit_message:
Add retries to module installation with r10k

Since the modules are git cloned when installed via r10k and
clones may fail due to some network glich, adding retries should
help in these cases.

We randomly hit failures during git clone in RDO promotion
jobs running on ci.centos.org, adding retries to r10k
installation to handle those random failures.

Added function 'retry_cmd' which can also be used
with other commands.

Also squashed below two commits:-

Retry sealert command on failure

We randomly see issues while running sealert
in RDO puppet promotion pipeline, sealert fails with:-
"SELinux is disabled or we can't open a policy file"
As per logs selinux is enabled and selinuxfs is mounted
so seems it's some filesystem issue.

Locally was able to reproduce only with selinux disabled
or umount /sys/fs/selinux. Adding retries in hope to
fix these random failures.

Change-Id: Icb07742d328827a41132cdd6a6c2bcfa3cde11ec
(cherry picked from commit 425f454bdcb264eb80b305b67a5d4bcd4e04aadb)

Improve retry_cmd function to handle set -e

In run_tests.sh we use 'set -e' which makes
script fail as soon as error hit but we don't
want to fail in case of retries, this patch fixes it.

Change-Id: Ia33ff3dbb88317171143a43e5b1c674038187254
(cherry picked from commit ec57a35931babc9698a8399ca5c76773f069e377)

Change-Id: I5f3b94eaa5a65c76877363e9ca41684445c9cb12
(cherry picked from commit 8d5b34c5522c17f0246d208d0104c86e3325250e)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-02 23:21:33.000000000', 'message': "relinker: Rehash as we complete partitions

Previously, we would rely on replication/reconstruction to rehash
once the part power increase was complete. This would lead to large
I/O spikes if operators didn't proactively tune down replication.

Now, do the rehashing in the relinker as it completes work. Operators
should already be mindful of the relinker's I/O usage and are likely
limiting it through some combination of cgroups, ionice, and/or
--objects-per-second.

Change-Id: Ib5bf426cf38559091917f2d25f4f60183cd16354
"}, {'created': '2021-02-08 23:44:22.000000000', 'message': "relinker: Rehash as we complete partitions

Now, do the rehashing in the relinker as it completes work. Operators
should already be mindful of the relinker's I/O usage and are likely
limiting it through some combination of cgroups, ionice, and/or
--objects-per-second.

Change-Id: Ib5bf426cf38559091917f2d25f4f60183cd16354
"}, {'created': '2021-02-11 00:15:18.000000000', 'message': "relinker: Rehash as we complete partitions

--files-per-second.

Change-Id: Ib5bf426cf38559091917f2d25f4f60183cd16354
"}, {'created': '2021-02-11 19:31:53.000000000', 'message': "relinker: Rehash as we complete partitions

Previously, we would rely on replication/reconstruction to rehash
once the part power increase was complete. This would lead to large
I/O spikes if operators didn't proactively tune down replication.

Now, do the rehashing in the relinker as it completes work. Operators
should already be mindful of the relinker's I/O usage and are likely
limiting it through some combination of cgroups, ionice, and/or
--files-per-second.

Change-Id: Ib5bf426cf38559091917f2d25f4f60183cd16354
"}, {'created': '2021-02-12 23:50:44.000000000', 'message': 'relinker: Rehash as we complete partitions

Previously, we would rely on replication/reconstruction to rehash
once the part power increase was complete. This would lead to large
I/O spikes if operators didn't proactively tune down replication.

Now, do the rehashing in the relinker as it completes work. Operators
should already be mindful of the relinker's I/O usage and are likely
limiting it through some combination of cgroups, ionice, and/or
--files-per-second.

Also clean up empty partitions as we clean up. Operators with metrics on
cluster-wide primary/handoff partition counts can use them to monitor
relinking/cleanup progress:

 P  3N            .----------.
 a               /            '.
 r              /               '.
 t  2N         /       .-----------------
 i            /        |
 t           /         |
 i   N -----'---------'
 o
 n
 s   0 ----------------------------------
       t0   t1    t2   t3   t4    t5

At t0, prior to relinking, there are

    N := <replica count> * 2 ** <old part power>

primary partitions throughout the cluster and a negligible number of
handoffs.

At t1, relinking begins. In any non-trivial, low-replica-count cluster,
the probability of a new-part-power partition being assigned to the same
device as its old-part-power equivalent is low, so handoffs grow while
primaries remain constant.

At t2, relinking is complete. The total number of partitions is now 3N
(N primaries + 2N handoffs).

At t3, the ring with increased part power is distributed. The notion of
what's a handoff and what's a primary inverts.

At t4, cleanup begins. The "handoffs" are cleaned up as hard links and
now-empty partitions are removed.

At t5, cleanup is complete and there are now 2N total partitions.

Change-Id: Ib5bf426cf38559091917f2d25f4f60183cd16354
'}, {'created': '2021-02-13 05:29:13.000000000', 'message': 'relinker: Rehash as we complete partitions

Previously, we would rely on replication/reconstruction to rehash
once the part power increase was complete. This would lead to large
I/O spikes if operators didn't proactively tune down replication.

Now, do the rehashing in the relinker as it completes work. Operators
should already be mindful of the relinker's I/O usage and are likely
limiting it through some combination of cgroups, ionice, and/or
--files-per-second.

Also clean up empty partitions as we clean up. Operators with metrics on
cluster-wide primary/handoff partition counts can use them to monitor
relinking/cleanup progress:

 P  3N            .----------.
 a               /            '.
 r              /               '.
 t  2N         /       .-----------------
 i            /        |
 t           /         |
 i   N -----'---------'
 o
 n
 s   0 ----------------------------------
       t0   t1    t2   t3   t4    t5

At t0, prior to relinking, there are

    N := <replica count> * 2 ** <old part power>

primary partitions throughout the cluster and a negligible number of
handoffs.

At t1, relinking begins. In any non-trivial, low-replica-count cluster,
the probability of a new-part-power partition being assigned to the same
device as its old-part-power equivalent is low, so handoffs grow while
primaries remain constant.

At t2, relinking is complete. The total number of partitions is now 3N
(N primaries + 2N handoffs).

At t3, the ring with increased part power is distributed. The notion of
what's a handoff and what's a primary inverts.

At t4, cleanup begins. The "handoffs" are cleaned up as hard links and
now-empty partitions are removed.

At t5, cleanup is complete and there are now 2N total partitions.

Change-Id: Ib5bf426cf38559091917f2d25f4f60183cd16354

Previously, we would rely on replication/reconstruction to rehash
once the part power increase was complete. This would lead to large
I/O spikes if operators didn't proactively tune down replication.

Now, do the rehashing in the relinker as it completes work. Operators
should already be mindful of the relinker's I/O usage and are likely

relinking/cleanup progress:

 P  3N            .----------.
 a               /            '.
 r              /               '.
 t  2N         /       .-----------------
 i            /        |
 t           /         |
 i   N -----'---------'
 o
 n
 s   0 ----------------------------------
       t0   t1    t2   t3   t4    t5

At t0, prior to relinking, there are

    N := <replica count> * 2 ** <old part power>

primary partitions throughout the cluster and a negligible number of
handoffs.

At t1, relinking begins. In any non-trivial, low-replica-count cluster,
the probability of a new-part-power partition being assigned to the same
device as its old-part-power equivalent is low, so handoffs grow while
primaries remain constant.

At t2, relinking is complete. The total number of partitions is now 3N
(N primaries + 2N handoffs).

At t3, the ring with increased part power is distributed. The notion of
what's a handoff and what's a primary inverts.

At t4, cleanup begins. The "handoffs" are cleaned up as hard links and

commit_message:
relinker: Rehash as we complete partitions

Previously, we would rely on replication/reconstruction to rehash
once the part power increase was complete. This would lead to large
I/O spikes if operators didn't proactively tune down replication.

Now, do the rehashing in the relinker as it completes work. Operators
should already be mindful of the relinker's I/O usage and are likely
limiting it through some combination of cgroups, ionice, and/or
--files-per-second.

Also clean up empty partitions as we clean up. Operators with metrics on
cluster-wide primary/handoff partition counts can use them to monitor
relinking/cleanup progress:

 P  3N            .----------.
 a               /            '.
 r              /               '.
 t  2N         /       .-----------------
 i            /        |
 t           /         |
 i   N -----'---------'
 o
 n
 s   0 ----------------------------------
       t0   t1    t2   t3   t4    t5

At t0, prior to relinking, there are

    N := <replica count> * 2 ** <old part power>

primary partitions throughout the cluster and a negligible number of
handoffs.

At t1, relinking begins. In any non-trivial, low-replica-count cluster,
the probability of a new-part-power partition being assigned to the same
device as its old-part-power equivalent is low, so handoffs grow while
primaries remain constant.

At t2, relinking is complete. The total number of partitions is now 3N
(N primaries + 2N handoffs).

At t3, the ring with increased part power is distributed. The notion of
what's a handoff and what's a primary inverts.

At t4, cleanup begins. The "handoffs" are cleaned up as hard links and
now-empty partitions are removed.

At t5, cleanup is complete and there are now 2N total partitions.

Change-Id: Ib5bf426cf38559091917f2d25f4f60183cd16354

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-11 08:58:44.000000000', 'message': 'Fix update of trunk subports during live migration

During the live migration trunk subports where updated only based
on the "host_id" field. But when rpc message to update subports
is send trunk's port is still bound to the old host and has
"migrating_to" field in binding:profile set to the new host.
Because of that binding:host_id for the subport's port wasn't updated
proberly and port was set to DOWN on the new host.
That could even cause connectivity break if L2population is used in the
cloud.

This patch fixes that by updating subport's binding:host_id field based
on the migrating_to field if that is available and not empty.

Closes-Bug: #1914747
Change-Id: I98e55242d381ada642ca0729e9aefdea7628c945
(cherry picked from commit e05101c8ac953cc2823b35aaed3d499afc101988)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix update of trunk subports during live migration

During the live migration trunk subports where updated only based
on the "host_id" field. But when rpc message to update subports
is send trunk's port is still bound to the old host and has
"migrating_to" field in binding:profile set to the new host.
Because of that binding:host_id for the subport's port wasn't updated
proberly and port was set to DOWN on the new host.
That could even cause connectivity break if L2population is used in the
cloud.

This patch fixes that by updating subport's binding:host_id field based
on the migrating_to field if that is available and not empty.

Closes-Bug: #1914747
Change-Id: I98e55242d381ada642ca0729e9aefdea7628c945
(cherry picked from commit e05101c8ac953cc2823b35aaed3d499afc101988)

commit_message:
Add regression test for bug 1914777

This adds two tests to cover a regression where racing create and
delete requests could result in a user receiving a 500 error when
attempting to delete an instance:

  Unexpected exception in API method: AttributeError: 'NoneType' object
  has no attribute 'uuid'

Related-Bug: #1914777

Change-Id: I8249c572c6f727ef4ca434843106b9b57c47e585

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-18 07:46:25.000000000', 'message': 'Fix: cinder store test

With change[1], the validation check for volume type during service
startup happens for single store also. (previously only for multi store).
This introduced an additional call to get_cinderclient failing assert
in test_migrate_image_after_upgrade.
This patch fixes the same.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance_store/+/774703

Change-Id: I8852bb02732845c145cca9483b0b33e0a9d73d9e
'}, {'created': '2021-02-18 14:32:24.000000000', 'message': "Fix: cinder store test

With change[1], the validation check for volume type during service
startup happens for single store also. (previously only for multi store).
This introduced an additional call to get_cinderclient failing assert
in test_migrate_image_after_upgrade.
Similar code changes can cause future failures on glance gate and the code
changes doesn't exist in glance. To address this, this patch loosens

commit_message:
Fix: cinder store test

With change[1], the validation check for volume type during service
startup happens for single store also. (previously only for multi store).
This introduced an additional call to get_cinderclient failing assert
in test_migrate_image_after_upgrade.
Similar code changes can cause future failures on glance gate and the code
changes doesn't exist in glance. To address this, this patch loosens
up the strict checking on call count for every method and just verifies
it was called.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance_store/+/774703

Closes-Bug: #1916011
Change-Id: I8852bb02732845c145cca9483b0b33e0a9d73d9e

commit_message:
tools: Allow check-cherry-picks.sh to be disabled by an env var

The checks performed by this script aren't always useful to downstream
consumers of the repo so allow them to disable the script without having
to make changes to tox.ini.

NOTE(lyarwood): This backport has
Ie8a672fd21184c810bfe9c0e3a49582189bf2111 squashed into it to ensure the
introduced env var is passed into the pep8 tox env.

tox: Add passenv DISABLE_CHERRY_PICK_CHECK to pep8

I4f551dc4b57905cab8aa005c5680223ad1b57639 introduced the environment
variable to disable the check-cherry-pick.sh script but forgot to allow
it to be passed into the pep8 tox env.

Change-Id: I4f551dc4b57905cab8aa005c5680223ad1b57639
(cherry picked from commit 610396f8ad5fe8c3abb7731fcd42c81e5246a938)
(cherry picked from commit 3d86df068a7a78f8faa9ac6437ff4fc19f5cebcc)

commit_message:
Trigger deploy guide rebuild on a-r-r update

In deploy guide we rely on latest_tag to provide users with valid git tag
in the guide. However this is broken now, since deploy guide rebuild
is not triggered by jobs.

This change makes use of long ago added project-template that
also triggers build on a-r-r update comparing to it's original [1]

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/src/commit/9f64b09a4b9dee2c5adcde696b59c689237c5d7a/zuul.d/project-templates.yaml#L1628-L1649

Change-Id: I4708b2ad183b4c09582f723d6c114012c8a6ea17
(cherry picked from commit 98a10bca4bf1159ac062c32e213e4bb04b0d85ea)

commit_message:
Remove CentOS 7 image resolv.conf workaround

This workaround is no longer needed for current CentOS 8 images as
resolv.conf file comes now empty.

Moreover, the workaround has been preventing seed host configure from
running successfully on Ubuntu hosts.

Change-Id: I30e34e3c58db3f3a93a07f3d6d53671286e4260e

commit_message:
Support to restore backup from remote location

In multi-region deployment with geo-replicated Swift, the user can
restore a backup in one region by manually specifying the original
backup data location created in another region.

Change-Id: Iefef3bf969163af707935445bc23299400dc88c3

commit_message:
Change the default agent_heartbeat_expiry to 90s

By default, trove guest agent is sending health heartbeat msg for every
60s, so agent_heartbeat_expiry should be bigger than that.

Change-Id: I348a82aa948079b7bba5c172b8d57d5f5dee28a0

subject: Bump minimum version for PyYAML to 5.1
messages:
[{'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2021-02-18 15:47:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-02-18 15:54:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Can't we move directly to 5.4.1?

https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/commit/ee37f4653c08fc07aecff69cfd92848e6b1a540e"}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2021-02-18 16:39:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2
> 
> Can't we move directly to 5.4.1?
> 
> https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/commit/ee37f4653c08fc07aecff69cfd92848e6b1a540e

This is just to avoid using vulnerable versions of PyYAML (<5.1). I'm not aware of any reason we need to bump the minimum further. If there is one we can certainly do that though."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-02-18 17:55:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2021-02-18 18:03:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hmm, apparently we're still validating lower-contraints even though we don't use them. I'll have to update that too for this to pass."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2021-02-18 18:05:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-02-18 18:20:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Can you rebase onto https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.config/+/771102 ?'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2021-02-18 18:24:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-02-18 18:31:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Already had a +2 from hberaud so I'm carrying that"}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2021-02-18 19:38:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

While I don't strongly object to this change, it's worth noting that CVE-2017-18342 was entirely about the potential for projects consuming pyyaml to pass untrusted data to load() instead of relying on safe_load(). A quick audit of the current state of oslo.config suggests this is not actually a risk, so running it with older versions of pyyaml shouldn't result in an vulnerable situation regardless."}]

commit_message:
Bump minimum version for PyYAML to 5.1

This addresses CVE-2017-18342. I doubt anyone is actually using an
old version of PyYAML with oslo.config at this point, but that means
it shouldn't hurt to bump the minimum either.

Change-Id: I4f440eb9511333ce70db4184857dcbcdd0ed1b97
Closes-Bug: 1839398

commit_message:
Specify manila microversion header

Manila API honors a "X-OpenStack-Manila-API-Version"
header to specify microversions.

It may support the OpenStack-API-Version header
in a future release, however, we'll need to maintain
backwards compatibility with the existing API.

Change-Id: Ia2e62d3a11a08adeb6d488b7c9b365f7ff2be3c8

commit_message:
Align doc with new Pygments

After Pygments update to 2.8.0 [1] it updated the way it
interpret console blocks after this change [2].
So we are making new Pygments happy about new lines.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/673ce445d54f8bdf792550e2d9cfdf23bffa5f83
[2] https://github.com/pygments/pygments/pull/1672

Change-Id: Ica9cbe8dc0a9186b68d59d40cb2549c2dc7110db

commit_message:
Switch to collections.abc.MutableMapping

collections.MutableMapping has been deprecated since Python 3.3 and
is removed in Python 3.10. The functionality should be identical.

Change-Id: Ic9b2f8a89a92ac3a5fa5f49bb19f13e547d12eda

[{'created': '2021-02-17 17:03:37.000000000', 'message': 'Allow rhsm subscription test to be overrided in RHOSP deployment.

This allow the master playbook used for update to set
tripleo_redhat_enforce to false on a per role basis on Red Hat
environment.

The default in defaults/main.yml is now "true" so that it keeps its
behavior of being run by default if nothing is changed in the role
definition.

We then avoid running it on other plateform than Red Hat by adding an
explicit test in that tasks/main.yml file.

Overall the behavior is as follows:

  | Red Hat Env | tripleo_enforced     | Test run |
  |-------------+----------------------+----------|
  | True        | Unset                | Yes      |
  | True        | Set to true in role  | Yes      |
  | True        | Set to false in role | No       |
  | False       | Doesn't matter       | No       |

Change-Id: I6268a01d16f8288bf862003d19184fc93b88282a
Partial-Bug: #1912512
(cherry picked from commit c7dadde9505e35f7cee0d2d1cef40fcd60a8293e)
'}]
commit_message:
Allow rhsm subscription test to be overrided in RHOSP deployment.

This allow the master playbook used for update to set
tripleo_redhat_enforce to false on a per role basis on Red Hat
environment.

The default in defaults/main.yml is now "true" so that it keeps its
behavior of being run by default if nothing is changed in the role
definition.

We then avoid running it on other plateform than Red Hat by adding an
explicit test in that tasks/main.yml file.

Overall the behavior is as follows:

  | Red Hat Env | tripleo_enforced     | Test run |
  |-------------+----------------------+----------|
  | True        | Unset                | Yes      |
  | True        | Set to true in role  | Yes      |
  | True        | Set to false in role | No       |
  | False       | Doesn't matter       | No       |

Change-Id: I6268a01d16f8288bf862003d19184fc93b88282a
Partial-Bug: #1912512
(cherry picked from commit c7dadde9505e35f7cee0d2d1cef40fcd60a8293e)

3600 seconds is 1 hour and not 24 hours, and 900 seconds is 15 mins

Change-Id: I74cc8a01468444307619a05f4830ce6cf87240ab

commit_message:
Fix memcached host address.

Since pymemcache 3.4.0, localhost will first translate to ipv6 ([::1])
if possible instead of ipv4 (127.0.0.1). Since memcached is running in
the ipv4 interface, we need to point tooz to the right endpoint.

Conflicts:
  zuul.d/ironic-inspector-jobs.yaml

NOTE(moguimar): Conflicts are due small difference in adjacent lines.

Signed-off-by: Mois√©s Guimar√£es de Medeiros <moguimar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Iddf558cd598e41ffead11e164ce2fb1720d15f34
(cherry picked from commit 86b974b75ca998caea8ca949f01d514a00e2ff96)
(cherry picked from commit 965a4f5086b2fa8a9dd0d80af2be28872db3d44f)

commit_message:
Prevent redfish-virtual-media from being used with Dell nodes

Indicate that idrac-redfish-virtual-media must be used instead,
otherwise a confusing failure will happen.

commit_message:
Use unix socket to connect libvirt in nova

The motivation is to remove 127.0.0.1 in connection_uri and so
can allow live migration in libvirtd.
Plus, realize tls on libvirt to secure.
Now /run is already mounted so it should work

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/752263
Change-Id: I911abb8b1ee1e300d02a373e083a404574cc3fea

commit_message:
Fix node delete to not use overcloud plan

This also moves some helper functions from tripleo-common
mistral action to utils.py. A subsequent patch would
cleanup the mistral actions in tripleo-common.

Closes-Bug: #1915780

commit_message:
Drop ppc64le installs of biosdevname, efibootmgr, efivar

UEFI 2.8 only supports Intel, ARM and RISC-V

    https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-common/+/773010/

... to break ppc64le IPA image builds.

Signed-off-by: Lon Hohberger <lhh@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ia74d6aa659f5d705eeea931a4332f08b8bdcb2a3

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-03 05:25:21.000000000', 'message': "Don't create deployment when changing transport

Earlier when changing software config transport we used to
create a dummy deployment to push the metadata. However
this would not work with convergence as we take
resource lock for the update which updates the config
transport (another engine would try to update the resource
metadata for deployment when one engine has locked it).

Currently it works when updating transport as we ignore
the error in creating dummy deployment, but if there are
any new depoyments for the server they would fail.

We don't need to push the metadata as it would be pushed
when the there is a new/updated deployment.

Few additional changes in the patch:

- We don't need to ignore the error as servers are now
not replaced if the resource is in ERROR when nova server
is good/ACTIVE.
- Delete the existing tempurls and zaqar queues when
  changing transport.

Task: 41744
Change-Id: Id592b29df36320d8697bd370252ada02612ba7d0
"}]
commit_message:
Don't create deployment when changing transport

Earlier when changing software config transport we used to
create a dummy deployment to push the metadata. However
this would not work with convergence as we take
resource lock for the update which updates the config
transport (another engine would try to update the resource
metadata for deployment when one engine has locked it).

Currently it works when updating transport as we ignore
the error in creating dummy deployment, but if there are
any new depoyments for the server they would fail.

We don't need to push the metadata as it would be pushed
when the there is a new/updated deployment.

Few additional changes in the patch:

- We don't need to ignore the error as servers are now
not replaced if the resource is in ERROR when nova server
is good/ACTIVE.
- Delete the existing tempurls and zaqar queues when
  changing transport.

Task: 41744
Change-Id: Id592b29df36320d8697bd370252ada02612ba7d0

subject: Fix node id vs uuid in processing_logger_prefix
messages: [{'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-02-18 15:25:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2021-02-18 15:26:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-18 15:25:12.000000000', 'message': 'Fix node id vs uuid in processing_logger_prefix

this is a follow-up to Icd3de82877c6a53d32b4c9fd3e500d3cd9d7fb17

one more place was identified as trying to use uuid attr of a Node
object from openstacksdk instead of id attr.

In tests, use stricter mocking with spec_set (that actually fails to
access or set an atribute of a mock that is absent from the spec class
or instance) to guard against future possible changes.

Change-Id: I83c420d0e91e00f583a28833f4f710cf70b01fa8
Story: 2008379
Task: 41300
(cherry picked from commit 5c79d7552a76adc27b7246b411312ab832a0f28b)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix node id vs uuid in processing_logger_prefix

this is a follow-up to Icd3de82877c6a53d32b4c9fd3e500d3cd9d7fb17

one more place was identified as trying to use uuid attr of a Node
object from openstacksdk instead of id attr.

In tests, use stricter mocking with spec_set (that actually fails to
access or set an atribute of a mock that is absent from the spec class
or instance) to guard against future possible changes.

Change-Id: I83c420d0e91e00f583a28833f4f710cf70b01fa8
Story: 2008379
Task: 41300
(cherry picked from commit 5c79d7552a76adc27b7246b411312ab832a0f28b)

commit_message:
Trigger deploy guide rebuild on a-r-r update

In deploy guide we rely on latest_tag to provide users with valid git tag
in the guide. However this is broken now, since deploy guide rebuild
is not triggered by jobs.

This change makes use of long ago added project-template that
also triggers build on a-r-r update comparing to it's original [1]

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/src/commit/9f64b09a4b9dee2c5adcde696b59c689237c5d7a/zuul.d/project-templates.yaml#L1628-L1649

Change-Id: I4708b2ad183b4c09582f723d6c114012c8a6ea17
(cherry picked from commit 98a10bca4bf1159ac062c32e213e4bb04b0d85ea)

commit_message:
pip3 binary missing, switch to use python -m pip

C7 jobs are failing with below error, details in bug:-
~~~
sudo: pip3: command not found
~~~

We are mixing installation of rpm and source at various places.
Switching to "python -m pip" as its more safer option when pip binary
is missing.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1915932
Closes-Bug: #1915932

Change-Id: I3ac50a92ba14a1432f02463211caba87d08a51f1

commit_message:
Reference the installed gpg key when setting up the EPEL repository

Building a chroot using dnf fails if the yum repo config does not
contain the url of the gpg key. This key url is present in the other
repo config files on a centos-8 stream system.

Change-Id: I97ad5d9f210a17a6a19f31c7e6cadee595dc7dca

commit_message:
Propose a release model change for Vitrage-dashboard

Deliverables was only released once during the last cycle, and have not done a release yet

It could be the right time to switch to the cycle-with-rc model.
PTLs and release liaisons please:
- immediately release an intermediary release (and -1 the proposed change)
- confirm the release model change (+1 the proposed change)
- stay uncertain for this cycle of how many releases will be made,
  but acknowledge that they need to do a release before RC1
  (-1 the proposed change)

Change-Id: I5bfd701e6059d2dfdc645bb5f2c7a4da249ad1f2

commit_message:
Propose a release model change for Swift

Deliverables was only released once during the last cycle, and have not done a release yet

It could be the right time to switch to the cycle-with-rc model.
PTLs and release liaisons please:
- immediately release an intermediary release (and -1 the proposed change)
- confirm the release model change (+1 the proposed change)
- stay uncertain for this cycle of how many releases will be made,
  but acknowledge that they need to do a release before RC1 (-1 the proposed change)

Change-Id: Icef26026e4388d21ad61a759055df08c3fd53655

The Neutron project meets all the requirements for the api interop tag.
It follow the api interop guidelines, supports API discoverablity by
using extensions mechanism, and has branchless API testing through
tempest and neutron-tempest-plugin.

Change-Id: Ica7ed7e3cdc146b3d9de268f0414d8d33c1090fa
'}]
commit_message:
Add assert:supports-api-interoperability tag to neutron

The Neutron project meets all the requirements for the api interop tag.
It follow the api interop guidelines, supports API discoverablity by
using extensions mechanism, and has branchless API testing through
tempest and neutron-tempest-plugin.

[{'created': '2021-02-02 13:37:56.000000000', 'message': 'Add assert:supports-api-interoperability to cinder

The Cinder project meets all the requirements for the api
interoperability tag:

1 - The project follows the OpenStack API interoperability
    guidelines [0] when making changes to the REST API
2 - The Block Storage API v3 uses the microversions versioning
    scheme
3 - Branchless API tests from tempest and the cinder-tempest-plugin
    run on every commit

[0] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/api_interoperability.html

Change-Id: Ie8b2231126db01707507320a3597a398fa208ae8
'}]
commit_message:
Add assert:supports-api-interoperability to cinder

The Cinder project meets all the requirements for the api
interoperability tag:

1 - The project follows the OpenStack API interoperability
    guidelines [0] when making changes to the REST API
2 - The Block Storage API v3 uses the microversions versioning
    scheme
3 - Branchless API tests from tempest and the cinder-tempest-plugin
    run on every commit

[0] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/api_interoperability.html

Change-Id: Ie8b2231126db01707507320a3597a398fa208ae8

commit_message:
Retire tempest-horizon

As disscussed in Wallaby PTG [1], QA and Horizon team decided to
move the horizon dashboard test from tempest-horizon to Tempest.
Scenario tests in tempest-horizon have been merged into the tempest
repository. tempest-horizon is branchless so we can retire it
without a deprecation phase.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/project-config/+/774378
Change-Id: Ie18ae4891d41e39d9cb23aee50f11b329e724172

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-29 15:33:39.000000000', 'message': 'Release senlin for stable/train

This release picks up new commits to senlin since
the last release from stable/train.

This is being proposed as a convenience to help make sure stable
changes are being released. If the team is good with this going out,
please respond with a +1 to let the release team know it is OK to
proceed.

If it is not wanted at this time, or if there are more changes that
would be good to get merged before doing a  stable release, please
leave a -1 with a comment with what the team would prefer. We can
then either abandon this patch, or wait for an update with a new
commit hash to use instead.

Signed-off-by: Elod Illes <elod.illes@est.tech>
Change-Id: I840c81da1d2fb364fd1213288b10d70caa8a1462
'}]
commit_message:
Release senlin for stable/train

This release picks up new commits to senlin since
the last release from stable/train.

This is being proposed as a convenience to help make sure stable
changes are being released. If the team is good with this going out,
please respond with a +1 to let the release team know it is OK to
proceed.

If it is not wanted at this time, or if there are more changes that
would be good to get merged before doing a  stable release, please
leave a -1 with a comment with what the team would prefer. We can
then either abandon this patch, or wait for an update with a new
commit hash to use instead.

Signed-off-by: Elod Illes <elod.illes@est.tech>
Change-Id: I840c81da1d2fb364fd1213288b10d70caa8a1462

commit_message:
Adding resize_volume to BlockStorageCloudMixin

We are missing some "/action" operations for volumes so this patch
adds the ability to resize volumes to the sdk.

Signed-off-by: Thiago Brito <thiago.brito@windriver.com>

playbooks in an ephemeral heat stack. The cloud-admin user is also

commit_message:
Add cloud-admin user to tripleoclient container

osp-director-operator use tripleoclient pod to render the ansible
playbooks in an ephemeral heat stack. The cloud-admin user is also
used as default deployment user to run the ansible playbooks to
deploy the overcloud.

This also adds osc-placement to the container image which allows
to query placment direct using osc.

Change-Id: I38fe6419a6e18693adad79083a589f3a417de02f

subject: Unstack series on the "Cost Per Service Per Hour" graph
messages:
[{'account_id': 25277, 'date': '2021-02-02 13:06:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25277, 'date': '2021-02-02 13:08:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 25277, 'date': '2021-02-02 13:11:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Please read https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2008582 for details.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2021-02-02 13:35:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Review-Priority+1

I agree. Stacking series can lead people to misunderstanding. I do see a problem, if we have too many VMs for instance to display there.  However, this is something that we can introduce later with a filter option for instance.'}, {'account_id': 25277, 'date': '2021-02-02 16:10:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks, Rafael. You are right - multiple series with similar values may overlap if areas are not stacked. Do you foresee any backlash from users that would not be happy with this change because they are used to the form this data had been presented to them? Would setting this graph to use the 'line' renderer instead make it more readable? (here is how the sample graph would look like with lines instead of areas: https://github.com/mkarpiarz/cloudkitty-playground/blob/cost-per-service-per-h-graph/images/cloudkittydashboard_cost_per_service_per_hour_graph_line_renderer.png)"}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2021-02-02 17:15:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> Thanks, Rafael. You are right - multiple series with similar values may overlap if areas are not stacked. Do you foresee any backlash from users that would not be happy with this change because they are used to the form this data had been presented to them? Would setting this graph to use the 'line' renderer instead make it more readable? (here is how the sample graph would look like with lines instead of areas: https://github.com/mkarpiarz/cloudkitty-playground/blob/cost-per-service-per-h-graph/images/cloudkittydashboard_cost_per_service_per_hour_graph_line_renderer.png)

I do prefer the line trending than the one we are currently using. 
I would not worry much about people complaining. The method you are proposing, specially with the line trends makes more sense to me. What we could do then, is to create a "virtual" trend that would aggregate all of the others. What do you think?'}, {'account_id': 25277, 'date': '2021-02-02 17:24:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> > Patch Set 2:
> > 
> > Thanks, Rafael. You are right - multiple series with similar values may overlap if areas are not stacked. Do you foresee any backlash from users that would not be happy with this change because they are used to the form this data had been presented to them? Would setting this graph to use the 'line' renderer instead make it more readable? (here is how the sample graph would look like with lines instead of areas: https://github.com/mkarpiarz/cloudkitty-playground/blob/cost-per-service-per-h-graph/images/cloudkittydashboard_cost_per_service_per_hour_graph_line_renderer.png)
> 
> I do prefer the line trending than the one we are currently using. 
> I would not worry much about people complaining. The method you are proposing, specially with the line trends makes more sense to me. What we could do then, is to create a "virtual" trend that would aggregate all of the others. What do you think?

Yes, I've been thinking about an extra series that would sum all points for each X. Though this might not be as simple as I think and is probably something for a different story. :)'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2021-02-08 10:19:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Please add a reno release note. Also, do you have a screenshot of what the graph looks like with this patch?'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2021-02-08 10:22:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Unstack series on the "Cost Per Service Per Hour" graph

By default series on the "Cost Per Service Per Hour" graph are stacked
together which means:

* all series have to have the same length, otherwise Rickshaw/D3 won't
  be able to stack them up;
* series are drawn one over another and since they are area graphs, this
  gives false impression of scale (series other than the first one will
  appear higher than what the scale on the Y axis suggests)

This change disables stacking of data series.

Story: 2008582
Task: 41735

Change-Id: I6aed92383a70f8dcf26c45155ef1d16169d40601

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Change-Id: Ied61e65006ad54803453776e763594e216be1353

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-22 08:54:48.000000000', 'message': "Add a tutorial illustrating versioning

* While working on the spec for generic os-vif datapath offloads[1], it
  became apparent that there's a gap in o.vo's developer-facing documentation
  detailing the interactions between versioning, inheritance and
  composition.

* All the information in this commit can be sourced from various blogs,
  example code and tests, but it is convenient to have a succinct
  summary in one place.

* Finally, this documentation tries to establish a pattern that that is
  rigorous and simple to implement.

[1]: http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/stein/approved/generic-os-vif-offloads.html

Change-Id: I948a708f10dfe5ff9f031e71cba30a881a9b261d
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Add a tutorial illustrating versioning

* While working on the spec for generic os-vif datapath offloads[1], it
  became apparent that there's a gap in o.vo's developer-facing documentation
  detailing the interactions between versioning, inheritance and
  composition.

* All the information in this commit can be sourced from various blogs,
  example code and tests, but it is convenient to have a succinct
  summary in one place.

* Finally, this documentation tries to establish a pattern that that is
  rigorous and simple to implement.

[1]: http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/stein/approved/generic-os-vif-offloads.html

Change-Id: I948a708f10dfe5ff9f031e71cba30a881a9b261d
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>

commit_message:
Moves centos-7-scenario-multinode queens jobs to deprecated-jobs

These jobs are non voting and deprecating these is part of a wider
effort to reduce our CI footprint see [1]. Deprecating instead of
removing so we don't block on places still using them, like [2].

Once they are removed from all layouts we can delete them from
deprecated-jobs.yaml

[1] https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:tripleo-ci-reduce
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/aodh/+/776116

Change-Id: I93dadae4999679b5f54acdc1c459ce5806b1386e

subject: Fix node id vs uuid in processing_logger_prefix
messages:
[{'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2021-02-17 15:14:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10288, 'date': '2021-02-17 15:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-02-17 15:18:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

I wonder if it's possible to unit test this fix."}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2021-02-17 16:01:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

@Dmitry, I'll have to modify the tests anyway, currently they are failing

IN unit tests, the node object is mocked out, and thus whatever we set on it - works, the usual bane of mocks and unit tests.. :-/

May be we can instantiate a real Node object from openstacksdk but mock out some of its parts that access outside..."}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2021-02-17 16:42:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2021-02-17 16:45:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

found solution for unit tests - use spec_set [0] instead of simply spec

https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/unittest.mock.html#unittest.mock.Mock

we should be using it more...'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2021-02-17 18:40:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

thanks!'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-02-18 13:26:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-17 15:14:25.000000000', 'message': 'Fix node id vs uuid in processing_logger_prefix

this is a follow-up to Icd3de82877c6a53d32b4c9fd3e500d3cd9d7fb17

one more place was identified as trying to use uuid attr of a Node
object from openstacksdk instead of id attr.

Change-Id: I83c420d0e91e00f583a28833f4f710cf70b01fa8
Story: 2008379
Task: 41300
'}, {'created': '2021-02-17 16:42:55.000000000', 'message': 'Fix node id vs uuid in processing_logger_prefix

this is a follow-up to Icd3de82877c6a53d32b4c9fd3e500d3cd9d7fb17

one more place was identified as trying to use uuid attr of a Node
object from openstacksdk instead of id attr.

In tests, use stricter mocking with spec_set (that actually fails to
access or set an atribute of a mock that is absent from the spec class
or instance) to guard against future possible changes.

Change-Id: I83c420d0e91e00f583a28833f4f710cf70b01fa8
Story: 2008379
Task: 41300
'}]
commit_message:
Fix node id vs uuid in processing_logger_prefix

this is a follow-up to Icd3de82877c6a53d32b4c9fd3e500d3cd9d7fb17

one more place was identified as trying to use uuid attr of a Node
object from openstacksdk instead of id attr.

In tests, use stricter mocking with spec_set (that actually fails to
access or set an atribute of a mock that is absent from the spec class
or instance) to guard against future possible changes.

Change-Id: I83c420d0e91e00f583a28833f4f710cf70b01fa8
Story: 2008379
Task: 41300

subject: Stop non-pcmk services of manila and cinder during upgrade
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6796, 'name': 'Giulio Fidente', 'email': 'gfidente@redhat.com', 'username': 'gfidente'}, {'_account_id': 6816, 'name': 'Jesse Pretorius', 'email': 'jesse@odyssey4.me', 'username': 'jesse-pretorius'}, {'_account_id': 9003, 'name': 'Tom Barron', 'email': 'tpb@dyncloud.net', 'username': 'tbarron'}, {'_account_id': 11090, 'name': 'Sergii Golovatiuk', 'email': 'sgolovat@redhat.com', 'username': 'holser'}, {'_account_id': 11166, 'name': 'Lukas Bezdicka', 'email': 'social@v3.sk', 'username': 'xbezdick'}, {'_account_id': 16643, 'name': 'Goutham Pacha Ravi', 'email': 'gouthampravi@gmail.com', 'username': 'gouthamr'}, {'_account_id': 21129, 'name': 'Alan Bishop', 'email': 'abishop@redhat.com', 'username': 'ASBishop'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26343, 'name': 'Jose Luis Franco', 'email': 'jfrancoa@redhat.com', 'username': 'jfrancoa'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-02-15 01:02:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-02-15 13:12:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Thank you for noticing and fixing this gap for the Manila services.

The -1 is just because we need to make sure the proposed handling of manila-share service is correct.  This service runs active-standby under pacemaker control, so only one controller runs it at any time -- same pattern as cinder-volume service.  A quick look didn't show service shut-down for un-upgraded controllers for cinder-volume.  Probably we'd skip it since either the service is running on the upgraded controller or should be left up until the controller on which it is running is upgraded so that the overall service isn't repeatedly shut down during the overall upgrade?"}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-02-15 13:22:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-02-15 13:39:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Thanks for explaining!

I'm going to add Alan Bishop for a followup question about deployment/cinder/cinder-volume-container-puppet.yaml."}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-02-15 13:43:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Alan - should there be a corresponding upgrade tasks change for deployment/cinder/cinder-volume-container-puppet.yaml ?  Downstream we don't actually use the corresponding manila file so we just need the fix for RDO but IIUC cinder does actually run w/o pacemaker at edges so upgrade tasks in this file might be relevant?"}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-02-15 13:51:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> @Alan - should there be a corresponding upgrade tasks change for deployment/cinder/cinder-volume-container-puppet.yaml ?  Downstream we don't actually use the corresponding manila file so we just need the fix for RDO but IIUC cinder does actually run w/o pacemaker at edges so upgrade tasks in this file might be relevant?

FYI I have submitted the change for standalone cinder-volume and cinder-backup here.
 https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/775544

AFAIK we don't support c-vol act/act in older releases, especially in Queens, so we don't expect any actual upgrade scenario with standalone cinder-volume service now. However I think it's better to implement the missing external_upgrade_tasks at this time for completeness"}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-02-15 14:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

I recommend combining this patch with cinder's. The fact that they're two different services doesn't matter. There's a tendency for developers to "forget" that cinder and manila have two THT variants (pacemaker and non-pcmk), and also the fact that manila is an optional service. I think the changes proposed in this and cinder's patch should have been included when external_upgrade_tasks were added to all the other tripleo services that run on controllers.'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-02-15 14:36:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-02-15 14:40:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

Thank you Alan for your quick feedback.

I squashed my change for cinder into this one as per your suggestion, and will abandon the change for cinder shortly.
I think I have upgrade my patch to address all of your suggestions in these 2 patches, but let me know if you have any additional feedback.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-02-15 15:36:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The header line is a bit misleading in that it suggests a contrast between the treatment of manila and cinder when in fact you are treating them similarly.  In both cases you are changing non-pcmk paths only and leaving the pcmk paths untouched.

[1] deployment/manila/manila-share-pacemaker-puppet.yaml'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-02-15 15:58:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-02-15 16:01:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2021-02-15 22:30:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

thanks;'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-02-15 22:47:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-02-15 23:06:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-02-16 04:28:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2021-02-16 11:10:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2021-02-16 14:07:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

+1 so that other people can review as well, but LGTM!'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2021-02-17 03:30:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

LGTM, thank you'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2021-02-17 03:31:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2021-02-18 10:45:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11166, 'date': '2021-02-18 10:47:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-15 01:02:41.000000000', 'message': 'Stop manila servics in unupgraded controllers

This change makes manila services on unupgrade controller nodes get
stopped, because all services in the unupgrade controllers should be
stopped before we start the upgraded controller[1].

[1] 8529ce60da84d2aa1e1c9e6994303678261b09da

Change-Id: I35ea4354a7448a23d6517f9777ed022caa79347a
'}, {'created': '2021-02-15 14:36:58.000000000', 'message': "Stop manila services and non-pcmk cinder services during upgrade

This change implements missing external_upgrade_tasks for manila
services and non-pcmk cinder services(cinder-volume and cinder-backup)
to ensure that we don't have mixed versions of controller services
running at the same time during upgrade.

These tasks should have been implemented in the initial patch[1], but
missed at that time unfortunately.

 [1] 8529ce60da84d2aa1e1c9e6994303678261b09da

Change-Id: I35ea4354a7448a23d6517f9777ed022caa79347a
"}, {'created': '2021-02-15 15:58:45.000000000', 'message': "Stop non-pcmk services of manila and cinder during upgrade

This change implements missing external_upgrade_tasks for non-pcmk
services of manila and cinder, to ensure that we don't have mixed
versions of controller services running at the same time during
upgrade.

These tasks should have been implemented in the initial patch[1], but
missed at that time unfortunately.

 [1] 8529ce60da84d2aa1e1c9e6994303678261b09da

Change-Id: I35ea4354a7448a23d6517f9777ed022caa79347a
"}]
commit_message:
Stop non-pcmk services of manila and cinder during upgrade

This change implements missing external_upgrade_tasks for non-pcmk
services of manila and cinder, to ensure that we don't have mixed
versions of controller services running at the same time during
upgrade.

These tasks should have been implemented in the initial patch[1], but
missed at that time unfortunately.

 [1] 8529ce60da84d2aa1e1c9e6994303678261b09da

Change-Id: I35ea4354a7448a23d6517f9777ed022caa79347a

[{'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-11-24 22:35:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-11-30 19:18:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7386, 'date': '2020-11-30 20:00:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Hi! I really like the idea behind Secure RBAC; it seems extremely flexible, which is great!

I do have a few questions, but I just want to make sure I understand the fundamental idea before I ask them. Just to make sure I understand, is the idea is to apply a more generic role/scope mapping to object permissions? So for example: right now, the values used to check `is_node_lessee` and `is_node_owner` are fetched from specific fields in a node. Would this change:

a) Allow for more generic object/project/role mapping - so instead of setting node A's lessee field, one could simply add "node A/$project/member" to the object/role map table.
b) Have Ironic objects expose these role mappings to policy, so policy rules can take these roles into account?'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2020-11-30 21:21:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(10 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2020-11-30 21:21:18.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to secure-rbac'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-12-01 00:28:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> Hi! I really like the idea behind Secure RBAC; it seems extremely flexible, which is great!
> 

\o/

> I do have a few questions, but I just want to make sure I understand the fundamental idea before I ask them. Just to make sure I understand, is the idea is to apply a more generic role/scope mapping to object permissions? So for example: right now, the values used to check `is_node_lessee` and `is_node_owner` are fetched from specific fields in a node. Would this change:
> 

I don't think that would change with this, I think it would only be embraced as we moved to support specific project and system scoped roles at the same time.


> a) Allow for more generic object/project/role mapping - so instead of setting node A's lessee field, one could simply add "node A/$project/member" to the object/role map table.

I have no desire, at least for now, to try and make this a per-node configuration matrix, if that is where your brain is headed. The idea is more so to support system and project scoped roles versus just  project scoped roles. That doesn't mean we can't. Just trying to keep the first pass scope in something sane.

> b) Have Ironic objects expose these role mappings to policy, so policy rules can take these roles into account?

AIUI, it is a bit in reverse. We gain an understanding of what the roles are and can make decisions from that. Given the field delineation, I wasn't thinking anything substantially different which would ultimately require per-object permissions capability. Again, not ruling that out eventually, just not a short term item in my perception.'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2020-12-01 02:41:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Ah, I think I get it now: this spec is about the introduction of *new* roles that match those in the secure RBAC world. These roles would not affect current `is_node_lessee` and `is_node_owner` determinations; however the desire in the long-term would be for some convergence favoring the new secure RBAC roles. And the major question answered in this spec is what API access the new secure RBAC scope/role pairings would have.

Did I get that right?'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-12-02 21:55:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(30 comments)

I would like to see this spec go in to more detail on reasoning behind making this change, particularly in the opening paragraphs. It's only later that "System scope" and "Project scope" are defined, and it still takes imagination from the reader to understand the use-cases.

I also think it would be a nice indicator of policy symmetry if Nova were able to use Project-scoped authorization for most operations, because that would imply the end-user would have been able to make those exact Ironic API calls themselves if they so desired.

It would be even cooler if the goal of the spec were restated in terms of that ^ sort of "policy symmetry" [0]. IOW, it should be stated all of the cases where Nova is still *required* to use a System-scoped authorization are considered to be weaknesses/bugs in Ironic.

[0] rather than the more obscure "Secure RBAC" term that is never actually defined or linked'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-12-04 23:00:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi! I think this spec is good; seeing the proposed implementation of the common personas in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ironic/+/763255 helped clarify a lot for me in terms of how the spec would be implemented.

One feature of that implementation is that a node's `owner` is essentially equivalent to the `project_id` found in other OpenStack projects: you're a PROJECT_ADMIN if you're an admin in the owner project, a PROJECT_MEMBER if you're a member in the owner project, etc. Then lessee is added into the mix as an additional way to be defined as a PROJECT_MEMBER. I'm not sure this idea is fully expressed in the spec; perhaps it's worth calling out for clarity?"}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2021-01-26 19:45:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

(11 comments)

(10 comments)

Great start. Thanks for detailed proposal.
But we need to look at it from the use-cases point of view.
To my recollections MASS supports the baremetal as a service model.
That is a subset of HW resources is delegated to tenant admin to manage.
That includes servers, networking and storage. Thus, servers can be configured and manage any way tenant admin wants. Current draft does not support all of these.
What happens to switches that we have rudiment of support in Ironic? Maybe pass a portgroup to tenant to own.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-02-08 16:54:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

> Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1
> 
> (10 comments)
> 
> Great start. Thanks for detailed proposal.

Thanks

> But we need to look at it from the use-cases point of view.

Okay, except the use cases were already agreed upon. There is no real opt out of the use cases.

> To my recollections MASS supports the baremetal as a service model.

And so does Ironic.

> That is a subset of HW resources is delegated to tenant admin to manage.

This is the owner or lessee models, both which were agreed upon in the community in the past. The purpose of this specification is to make ironic's resource authorization model consistent with the direction the rest of OpenStack.

> That includes servers, networking and storage. Thus, servers can be configured and manage any way tenant admin wants. Current draft does not support all of these.

I'm not sure we're on the same page since. I believe your incorrect since we're building on the prior models and what already exists through the owner/lessee models PLUS existing integrations.

> What happens to switches that we have rudiment of support in Ironic? Maybe pass a portgroup to tenant to own.

I think you want to be using project or project_id instead of tenant in this case, since everything is modeled around use of project ids to support the human or programmatic tenant associated with that project ID.

In essence, ports exist as objects which are part of a node. They are like attributes. If the baremetal node's owner or lessee have some sort of access, they should be able to access and use those artifacts. Owner admins may need to be granted more rights, but those exact details are more of an in-review consensus driven item and could always be added to or upon later as the need arises. At the end of the day, as long as we also provide a policy knob that operators can turn if needed.

At the end of the day, the lessee or the owner of a node has use of the ports and networking, and they should be able to leverage the cinder integration as well. Almost everything is based upon "can they access the node" and thus the resources associated to the node.

Regardless, a project ID can't independently own a portgroup on a node from the node itself. The node and portgroup are intrinsically associated and the items cannot be decoupled or parceled out. If they could be parceled out then we risk a situation where we would need to try and find a whole node to provide to an end user and it wouldn't then match the physical realities we want mapped in the data model so we can also tell the integrated services what they need to know for the physical integrations such as Neutron.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-02-08 17:15:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

AK: It for that subset of nodes project_id/tenant admin can do everything that system admin can do.

AK: If this model is restricted to server only it is OK. But it need to be stated. To my recollection Ironic did added support to switches also.

> 
> > What happens to switches that we have rudiment of support in Ironic? Maybe pass a portgroup to tenant to own.
> 
> I think you want to be using project or project_id instead of tenant in this case, since everything is modeled around use of project ids to support the human or programmatic tenant associated with that project ID.

AK: OK with that. I used portgroup for the switches as an example of entities for tenant admin to manage as part HW that is under his/her control for the duration of the lease. That actually brings a different question on duration of the lease and if system admin can revoke lease earlier. Part of lease management. Not sure to what degree keystone model supports it.

>

If the baremetal node's owner or lessee have some sort of access, they should be able to access and use those artifacts. Owner admins may need to be granted more rights, but those exact details are more of an in-review consensus driven item and could always be added to or upon later as the need arises. > 
> Regardless, a project ID can't independently own a portgroup on a node from the node itself. The node and portgroup are intrinsically associated and the items cannot be decoupled or parceled out. If they could be parceled out then we risk a situation where we would need to try and find a whole node to provide to an end user and it wouldn't then match the physical realities we want mapped in the data model so we can also tell the integrated services what they need to know for the physical integrations such as Neutron.'}, {'account_id': 7160, 'date': '2021-02-08 21:05:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(5 comments)

Thanks for very quick response Julia.
I think the use-case I am envisioning is that system admin manages a pool of resources and then leases a subset of a pool to "tenant admin" to do what they need. That means full control of these nodes. When done tenant admin returns node back to system admin after appropriate cleanup. For security reason system admin has no rights to a node while it is under tenant admin control until lease expired or some emergency.

To be fair this model is beyond Ironic usage for single OpenStack instance. 
But I view Ironic as serving more than strictly openstack.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-02-09 18:00:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

[trimed]
> 
> AK: It for that subset of nodes project_id/tenant admin can do everything that system admin can do.
> 

Thanks for the response label. Gerrit now reminds me so much of email. üòä

The model of use for both features if is the field is populated, they get selective but not full system-wide rights to the node.

[trimmed]
> 
> AK: If this model is restricted to server only it is OK. But it need to be stated. To my recollection Ironic did added support to switches also.

So I think your thinking of this through neutron integration as being part of ironic. We pass of physical switch port management to neutron. Those details remain unmodified and at most the data will be read-only unless we implement a specific policy.

As for the endpoints, the endpoints and how they, at least at a high level, are impacted is enumerated further down. There area a number of moving pieces to this work, but it also boils down, at least at the lower layers very neatly just to nodes and what is associated with them.


[trimmed]
> 
> AK: OK with that. I used portgroup for the switches as an example of entities for tenant admin to manage as part HW that is under his/her control for the duration of the lease. That actually brings a different question on duration of the lease and if system admin can revoke lease earlier. Part of lease management. Not sure to what degree keystone model supports it.
> 

It is not a keystone model really, it is a physical asset management model. Current consensus seems to be only system admins and system members may be able to update ports/portgroup specifics, which really isolates the ability. The access they could end up getting is really just "attach this vif to this node" access, which is exactly what exists today.

Proposes change to align with the Secure RBAC changes being
discussed upstream as part of the larger community.

commit_message:
Add a new role parameter rhsm_enforce.

With this new switch we can opt-out enforcement of the subscription
check for some composed role. This is mainly useful for composed Ceph
which have different constraint than other Openstack roles.

Closes-Bug: 1912512
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/775581


Change-Id: I46529ccab6c197da4885950282eb6731e28573d6
(cherry picked from commit d49fe9c60cc36e1c9774a94bc1f8eeff5d6aeeb1)
